unnormalised: ## Decoding the Labyrinth: My Brush with Indian Healthcare IDs
normalised: Decoding the Labyrinth: My Brush with Indian Healthcare I-Ds

unnormalised: So, there I was, armed with a doctor’s referral and a nagging cough, ready to tackle the Indian healthcare system. I thought, "piece of cake, I've dealt with worse bureaucracies." Oh, how wrong I was. It wasn't the medical stuff that got me; it was the identifiers – a whole new world of alphanumeric chaos.
normalised: So, there I was, armed with a doctor’s referral and a nagging cough, ready to tackle the Indian healthcare system. I thought, "piece of cake, I've dealt with worse bureaucracies." Oh, how wrong I was. It wasn't the medical stuff that got me; it was the identifiers – a whole new world of alphanumeric chaos.

unnormalised: First, there was my own ABHA ID. My friendly neighbourhood doctor, Dr. Sharma, at City Hospital, insisted on it. Said it was "for my own good." Apparently, it's supposed to link all my health records in one digital place. Sounds great, right? Except, I forgot my ABHA ID. I could only vaguely remember that it started with a "14" followed by a string of other seemingly random numbers. The process of retrieving it involved more clicks and OTPs than I care to remember. It was almost enough to make me forget about the cough.
normalised: First, there was my own A-B-H-A I-D. My friendly neighbourhood doctor, Doctor Sharma, at City Hospital, insisted on it. Said it was "for my own good." Apparently, it's supposed to link all my health records in one digital place. Sounds great, right? Except, I forgot my A-B-H-A I-D. I could only vaguely remember that it started with a "fourteen" followed by a string of other seemingly random numbers. The process of retrieving it involved more clicks and O-T-P-s than I care to remember. It was almost enough to make me forget about the cough.

unnormalised: Then came the insurance card. My family's health policy with Star Health, policy no. STH/HLTH/2023/12345, looked simple enough. Until the lady at the billing counter asked me for the "CGHS beneficiary ID." Apparently, my father's central government employee status meant there was *another* layer of ID to navigate. Turns out, my dad's CGHS card, with the ID 123456789012, was also needed for a special discount. Who knew healthcare came with so many secret levels?
normalised: Then came the insurance card. My family's health policy with Star Health, policy number S-T-H slash H-L-T-H slash two thousand and twenty three slash twelve thousand three hundred and forty five, looked simple enough. Until the lady at the billing counter asked me for the "C-G-H-S beneficiary I-D." Apparently, my father's central government employee status meant there was *another* layer of I-D to navigate. Turns out, my dad's C-G-H-S card, with the I-D one trillion two hundred and thirty four billion five hundred and sixty seven million eight hundred and ninety thousand one hundred and two, was also needed for a special discount. Who knew healthcare came with so many secret levels?

unnormalised: It didn't stop there. The hospital required a copy of my Aadhaar card, with its 12-digit number 4789 5643 2101, for "identification purposes." As if my ABHA ID, insurance card, and general aura weren't enough. I’m starting to feel like a walking, talking barcode. Each ID, I was told, served a unique and vital function, a cog in the machine of providing affordable and accessible healthcare to all Indians. But in the moment, it felt more like being lost in a maze designed by Kafka.

unnormalised: The next day, I decided to go for a second opinion at Global Health Clinic. This time, I was ready. ABHA ID memorised (mostly), insurance card laminated, Aadhaar copy fresh from the printer. I even had my father’s CGHS card downloaded on my phone. "Bring it on," I muttered to myself. However, this hospital needed my PAN (Permanent Account Number) which is ABCDE1234F. When asked what it was for, I was simply told that the hospital required it for records. It felt as if every aspect of my digital identity was being collected.

However, this hospital needed my P-A-N (Permanent Account Number) which is A-B-C-D-E-one-two-three-four-F. When asked what it was for, I was simply told that the hospital required it for records. It felt as if every aspect of my digital identity was being collected.

unnormalised: The sheer number of identifiers felt overwhelming. I began to wonder about the security and privacy implications. Was all this data really secure? Was it being used responsibly? It was enough to give anyone a headache, on top of their existing ailments.
normalised: The sheer number of identifiers felt overwhelming. I began to wonder about the security and privacy implications. Was all this data really secure? Was it being used responsibly? It was enough to give anyone a headache, on top of their existing ailments.

unnormalised: Now, don't get me wrong. I understand the need for identification and verification. It's crucial for preventing fraud and ensuring that people receive the right care. But perhaps there's a way to streamline the process, to reduce the burden on patients already dealing with health concerns. Maybe one super-ID to rule them all? (Okay, maybe not. That sounds a little too dystopian.)

unnormalised: Despite the identifier jungle, I eventually got the treatment I needed. And I learned a valuable lesson: when navigating the Indian healthcare system, come prepared. Bring your IDs, your patience, and maybe a good book to read while you're filling out forms. Oh, and don't forget your sense of humour. You'll need it.
